conclusion: The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of an object.
To find the displacement of Object A and Object B, calculate the area under each curve for the respective time intervals.
From t = 0 to t1: Object A starts with a high initial velocity v0 and decelerates uniformly to zero at t1. Object B starts with zero velocity and accelerates uniformly to v0 at t1.
At t1, both objects have traveled the same distance, so they meet at t1.
From t1 to t2: Object A remains stationary (velocity is zero). Object B continues to move with a constant velocity v0.
Since Object A is stationary and Object B moves forward, Object B will be ahead of Object A during this interval. They do not meet within this interval.
From t2 to t3: Object A accelerates uniformly from rest to v0 at t3. Object B decelerates uniformly from v0 to zero at t3.
At t3, both objects again have traveled the same additional distance since t1. Therefore, they meet again at t3.
From t3 to t4: Object A maintains a constant velocity v0. Object B accelerates uniformly from zero to some velocity by t4.
Since Object A maintains a constant velocity and Object B accelerates, Object A will be ahead of Object B during this interval. They do not meet within this interval.
The two objects meet at two distinct times: t1 and t3.
